Abb&combtildevert;is Abbatis de H&ydot;b&combtildevert;nia Hybernia · The encoding of punctuation marks here needs considerable work. The scribe uses a high curl between "Sancti" and "Brendani" and above the punctuation mark between "Brendani" and "Abbatis". Further, the abbreviation marker for both "at" in "Abbatis" and "er" in "Hybernia" is given with the default combining vertical tilde. However, they may well be considered separate marks (perhaps the former a hook), especially given that they represent separate letter strings. There is also a mark like an acute accent above the "a" in "Hybernia". It is hard to tell whether it is brown or red ink, and, consequently whether is is a stray or meaningful mark.

&dblsol; Is dernel˙&combmacr;ges an erþe ȝeue · and hider he scholle wendeHis dernelinges an erþe ȝyue · ȝ & hyder he &slong;chal wende·This line was apparently left blank by the original scribe and then filled in by a later one in lighter ink. The line is repeated in the left margin, also in lighter ink. The text written inline resembles the work of the scribe of the later saints's lives (Cecilia, Blaise, Alexius), especially in the characteristing use of "ȝ" for ampersand. The marginal text looks to be the same hand. The different spellings may be an attempt to blend in to the spellings of the surrounding text.
